articles.author: Dalton A. Breshears, J.D.
articles.description:
AI is no longer just a buzzword in the legal world‚Äîit's becoming a practical tool that law firms are using to dramatically speed up their workflows, especially when it comes to drafting motions, contracts, and legal research.
Faster Legal Research: Instead of spending hours combing through case law, attorneys are using AI-powered platforms like Lexis+ AI and Westlaw Precision to get contextual, relevant case summaries in seconds. These tools don‚Äôt just search‚Äîthey understand legal language and deliver insights, saving valuable time.
Drafting Motions & Contracts: AI tools like Harvey, CoCounsel by CaseText, and Spellbook are helping lawyers generate first drafts of everything from simple demand letters to complex motions. These platforms suggest clauses, format citations, and even flag potential risks‚Äîmaking it easier to move from outline to final draft in a fraction of the time.
Smarter Document Review: AI-powered review tools can now analyze contracts, flag missing provisions, and compare documents against standard templates. This is especially useful for due diligence, compliance checks, and M&A work.
Efficiency = Profitability: For law firms, time is literally money. By using AI to reduce manual work, they can focus on higher-level strategic thinking, serve more clients, and maintain accuracy under pressure.
AI isn‚Äôt replacing lawyers‚Äîit‚Äôs helping them work faster, smarter, and more effectively. The firms adopting these tools today are gaining a competitive edge in both service quality and speed.
articles.title: How Law Firms Are Using AI to Draft Faster and Work Smarter

articles.author: Rijul Rajesh
articles.description:
If you're starting with Rust, you've probably heard about Cargo. It‚Äôs the official package manager and build system for Rust, and it handles almost everything you need to get your Rust project up and running‚Äîfrom compiling code to managing dependencies. In this article, we‚Äôll take a closer look at how dependency management works using Cargo.toml.
Cargo.toml?


When you create a new Rust project using the command:
cargo new my_project

Cargo sets up a new project directory with a file called Cargo.toml. This file is the heart of your project configuration. It contains metadata about your project‚Äîlike its name, version, and authors‚Äîand, more importantly, a list of dependencies.
Here‚Äôs a simplified example of what a Cargo.toml might look like:
[package]
name = "my_project"
version = "0.1.0"
e‚Ä¶
articles.title: Getting Started with Dependency Management in Rust Using Cargo.toml

articles.author: Niko from Axrisi
articles.description:
This is a submission for Frontend Challenge - June Celebrations, CSS Art: June Celebrations.
I wanted to celebrate the joy and playfulness of National Donut Day through a purely CSS-driven illustration. Donuts are universally loved and instantly recognizable, so recreating one with only HTML and CSS felt like a fun test of creativity and technique. Drawing a frosted donut with colorful sprinkles allowed me to experiment with CSS gradients, shape techniques (using border-radius), and pseudo-elements for sprinkles. The challenge to avoid any images or JavaScript pushed me to think deeply about how CSS alone can convey a rich, mouth-watering design.





  
  
  Journey


When I began, I sketched a basic donut shape on paper to figure out proportions: a circular base, a slightly larger ring o‚Ä¶
articles.title: It's a DONUT!

articles.author: William Oliver
articles.description: Introduction Artificial intelligence systems don't exist in a vacuum. Every algorithm, every neural network, and every machine learning model carries within it the invisible fingerprints of human bias. As we increasingly rely on AI for critical decisions‚Äîfrom hiring employees to diagnosing diseases‚Äîunderstanding how machines absorb and amplify our prejudices has become one of the most pressing challenges in technology ethics. The relationship between human bias and machine learning isn't simply a technical problem to be solved with better code. It's a fundamental reflection of how our societies think, categorize, and make judgments about the world around us. Machine learning algorithms learn patterns from historical data, but this data often contains embedded societal biases. When we feed these datasets to AI systems, we're essentially teaching machines to perpetuate the same discriminatory patterns that exist in human society. Historical data reflection - Past hiring, lending, or judicial decisions embedded in training datasets Labeling inconsistencies - Human annotators applying subjective judgments during data preparation Representation gaps - Underrepresentation of certain demographic groups in training data Proxy discrimination - Using seemingly neutral variables that correlate with protected characteristics
articles.title: How Machines Learn Human Biases in Ethical AI

articles.author: Dmitry Titov
articles.description:
üöÄ Open source drives the modern web, but getting started can feel overwhelming ‚Äî especially for newcomers.
As part of an ongoing research project and upcoming publication, I'm running a short survey to understand how developers first entered the open source world, what challenges they faced, and what helped them stay.
üëâ Take the 3-minute anonymous survey here

Google Forms
This survey is for anyone who has ever tried contributing to open source ‚Äî whether you‚Äôre a regular contributor, a beginner, or someone who attempted it once.
I'm currently conducting research for a publication that explores how structured mentorship can help improve onboarding and retention in open source communities. Your input will help:
The results will be summarized in a public post, and may be used to inform future academic or community research efforts.
‚∏ª


  
  
  üì£ Spread the word


If you've been part of OSS in any way ‚Äî or tried to be ‚Äî I‚Äôd love your input.

And if you know someone who might have something to say, feel free to share üíô
Thanks in advance!

‚Äî Dmitrii Titov
articles.title: Help Improve Open Source Onboarding: 3-Minute Survey for Contributors

articles.author: Andr√°s Novosz√°th
articles.description:
One thing I learned about: How does Farcaster store data?
Farcaster seeks to connect users while balancing trust with scale.
It follows a mixed, on-chain/off-chain logic:
On-chain registry: creates accounts and keeps track of identities, permissions, and pointers.
Off-chain hubs: verifies, stores, syncs, and shares data (e.g. posts, follows).
User-facing clients: signs messages on behalf of the user and sends them to hubs.
NOTE: Farcaster has just moved its data layer from hubs to Snapchain.

üîΩüõ†Ô∏èResourcesüîΩ
Farcaster Docs: https://docs.farcaster.xyz/

Snapchain: https://github.com/farcasterxyz/snapchain
articles.title: ‚óºÔ∏è30/100 Block-by-Block How does Farcaster store data?

articles.author: Todd Sharp
articles.description:
Generative AI is excellent at analyzing large amounts of data and identifying and summarizing a meaningful subset of the data based on a guided set of instructions. The source of the data could be anything - your email inbox, a large text file on your machine or a webpage on the internet. It's not perfect, but it can give you a head start on large tasks that involve a lot of data. One of the things I get asked about a lot by developers is how they can use AI to analyze video content. Multimodal LLMs have come a long way, but they're not quite at the point where they could ingest an hour's worth of video from a live stream and provide a summary or identify potential clips for sharing on social media. But there's another approach that we can take to solve this problem.
In order to create a t‚Ä¶
articles.title: Auto-Generating Clips for Social Media from Live Streams with the Strands Agents SDK

articles.author: Leapcell
articles.description:
Leapcell: The Best of Serverless Web Hosting
Rust is often regarded as a systems programming language, but an increasing number of frameworks and practices demonstrate its suitability for full-stack web development:  
Tauri for cross-platform desktop applications


Leptos / Yew for frontend WebAssembly


Axum / Actix-web for backend services



Rust‚Äôs core design principles‚Äîmemory safety, zero-cost abstractions, and modern language features‚Äîmake it excel in web development scenarios. The following sections elaborate, from an engineering practice perspective, on how Rust addresses common pain points in web development and brings unique advantages.  
Rust makes errors explicit through Result<T, E> and prohibits implicit exceptions:
let body: RequestBody = serde_json::from_slice(&request_data‚Ä¶
articles.title: Building the Web with Rust: Here's Why It Matters

articles.author: Khelil Badro
articles.description: As developers, our tools can make or break our workflow ‚Äî and VS Code is one of the most powerful editors out there. Over the years, I‚Äôve tested dozens of extensions, but only a handful have truly stuck. In this post, I‚Äôm sharing the 10 VS Code extensions that I genuinely use every day ‚Äî the ones that boost my focus, code quality, and overall efficiency. Whether you're just starting out or looking to optimize your setup, these picks might just change your workflow too. My favorites include: GitLens for visualizing Git history inline, Prettier to auto-format code consistently, Tabnine/Codeium for AI-assisted autocomplete, Error Lens for inline linting, VS Code Icons to visually identify files, REST Client for testing APIs without Postman, npm Intellisense to autocomplete packages from node_modules, dotenv for .env syntax highlighting, TODO Highlight to keep track of tasks, and Project Manager to quickly switch between different projects. What‚Äôs your go-to VS Code extension? Drop it in the comments!
articles.title: 10 VS Code Extensions I Can‚Äôt Live Without in 2025
